content.raw: This note is not true anymore

I grabbed the all the latest merged changes and built all the 15 Ignition packages locally. Then, I sourced '`. ~/workspace/install/local_setup.bash'` Ignition libraries and built the ``tunnel_circuit` `` branch.  I also deleted all previous models under ~ /.iginition/fuel/… and launched using practice world 2.  Unfortunately, I didn't see any improvement.  I still cannot move the X1 robot neither manually or with logitech controller.  Has anyone else tested using the tunnel circuit practice worlds?   
  
`ign launch -v 4 tunnel_circuit_practice.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_02 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1`

![](data/bitbucket.org/repo/8zodKzn/images/2264323827-PR376.png)
content.html:
I grabbed the all the latest merged changes and built all the 15 Ignition packages locally. Then, I sourced '. ~/workspace/install/local_setup.bash' Ignition libraries and built the tunnel_circuit` branch. I also deleted all previous models under ~ /.iginition/fuel/… and launched using practice world 2. Unfortunately, I didn't see any improvement. I still cannot move the X1 robot neither manually or with logitech controller. Has anyone else tested using the tunnel circuit practice worlds?

ign launch -v 4 tunnel_circuit_practice.ign worldName:=tunnel_circuit_practice_02 robotName1:=X1 robotConfig1:=X1_SENSOR_CONFIG_1

update.description:
Final PR in this series of performance improvements. This requires: #!/ignitionrobotics/ign-msgs/pull-requests/143.

The main changes:

1. A `msgs::SerializedStateMap` message is used to help keep track of entities and components in a message so that we don't have to keep creating new messages.

2. A component knows when it has changed. Only changed components are serialized in the `msgs::SerializedStateMap`. This prevents static models from being serialized every iteration.

The major drawback to this PR is that log files generated by a previous version are not compatible with this change because the of the msgs change.

You should be able to run the example tunnel world faster than realtime. I saw between 110 and 120%.

```
ign gazebo -v 4 tunnel.sdf -z 100000 -r
```
update.title: Nate testing scenebroad improvements

content.raw: [![Build Status](https://build.osrfoundation.org/buildStatus/icon?job=ignition_gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64&build=715)](https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/715/) https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-abichecker-any_to_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/715/
Ubuntu is clean: https://build.osrfoundation.org/job/ignition_gazebo-ci-pr_any-ubuntu_auto-amd64/1860/
Good suggestions, but I don't have the time left to make any more changes. We can make improvements in default, targeting citadel.
content.html: Good suggestions, but I don't have the time left to make any more changes. We can make improvements in default, targeting citadel.

content.raw:
It will be tough to enforce that all component changes be done through this `SetChanged(SetData)` idiom.

Another upcoming use case to keep in mind is that once systems are updated in parallel, the ECM will need to resolve which changes have priority. With that in mind, how about adding a function like `RequestComponentChange` to the ECM, similar to `RequestEntityRemoval`, which marks the change and processes it after post-update? It would also be nice to prevent users from changing components in any other way, so we may need to get rid of the `Each` calls which provide access to non-const components.

All these changes could be cleaner if we targeted Citadel.
content.html:
It will be tough to enforce that all component changes be done through this SetChanged(SetData) idiom.

Another upcoming use case to keep in mind is that once systems are updated in parallel, the ECM will need to resolve which changes have priority. With that in mind, how about adding a function like RequestComponentChange to the ECM, similar to RequestEntityRemoval, which marks the change and processes it after post-update? It would also be nice to prevent users from changing components in any other way, so we may need to get rid of the Each calls which provide access to non-const components.

All these changes could be cleaner if we targeted Citadel.

perhaps elaborate as to what “lower performance impact” is here?

I assume using the non-const variant will always mark the data as changed, regardless if it was used for purely read-only operations.
